Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Synthetic Methodology through Total Synthesis of Complex Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Armen Zakarian of the University of California, Santa Barbara, is developing new methods and synthetic strategies for the preparation of a broad range of organic materials with useful properties. These methods are designed to make the synthesis of such materials from readily available sources shorter, and therefore more economical, energy-efficient, and less wasteful. The types of compounds that can be prepared using the new chemical tools find application primarily in pharmaceutical research and industry, and secondarily in materials and agricultural sciences.

The goals of this research project are two-fold. The first major goal is the development of modern C-H functionalization methods for the synthesis of benzofurans and benzofuran-containing natural products of biomedical significance, such as galanthamine. A copper-catalyzed direct aryl C-H functionalization method has been identified as highly promising to provide a path to functionalized benzofurans under mild conditions. Studies of its scope and application in the concise synthesis of galanthamine are being currently pursued. The second goal is the development of lanthanide catalysis for activation of dienes in the Diels Alder reaction. This approach features in the total synthesis of muironolide A, an exceedingly rare marine natural product with promising but unexplored biomedical potential. An outreach program is being developed between graduate students in the Zakarian group and area elementary school students and teachers involved in the SciTrak program hosted at UC Santa Barbara.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first total synthesis of muironolide A is one significant outcome of the award. Muironolide A is an new marine natural product isolated in microgram quantities which limited its further development. Our total synthesis accomlishment resulted in correction of its structure. Another intellectual merit of this work is the development of new reactions for broad applications i organic synthesis, especially demonstrating the potential of inverse-elecron demand Diels-Alder reaction of keto amides in the assembly of complex organic molecules.

The development of a new methods for the synthesis of benzofurans by Cu-catalyzed CH functionalization and nitrogen containing heterocycles also contribute the intellectual merit of this award. Benzofurans and similar heterocyclic compounds are important in medicinal and materials chemistry applications. 

We also reported a simple practical protocol for stereoselective fluorination of titanium enolates derived from N-acyl oxazolidinones. Fluorinated organic compounds are of broad importance in many areas of science and industry, such as agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, and new materials.

One of the most significant broader impacts of this award is in the training and education of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in chemical science that have high significance for society and technological development. Without the opportunities for research activities enabled by these awards it would be impossible to get younger talented students interested in highly rewarding careers in science and science-related technologies that benefit the entire society. 

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2018
Modified by: Armen Zakarian
